thread.title: Tuskegee 49, Stillman 20: Defense continues to set tone
thread.title_full: Tuskegee 49, Stillman 20: Defense continues to set tone

title: Tuskegee 49, Stillman 20: Defense continues to set tone
text:
Tuskegee 49, Stillman 20: Defense continues to set tone Kamarri Darrington 10:07 p.m. CDT October 17, 2015 Buy Photo A brief pregame incident sent coaching staff from both teams and other officials scrambling to get between Tuskegee and Stillman players on Saturday, Oct. 17, 2015, in Tuskegee. The incident was quickly calmed and both teams went on to play. The incident was quickly calmed and both teams went on to play. Shannon Heupel/Advertiser Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Tuskegee University's Golden Tigers took on the Stillman Tigers at home on Saturday, Oct. 17, 2015, in Tuskegee, Ala. Tuskegee took the win 49-20. (Photo: Shannon Heupel/Advertiser) 15 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TUSKEGEE — Tuskegee and Stillman couldn’t wait to start the fireworks on Saturday as both teams got into a shoving contest prior to running onto the field. 
That was all the fight Stillman had all day. 
Tuskegee defensive end Julian Morgan led the Golden Tigers with 11 tackles, seven tackles for loss, two fumble recoveries and four sacks as Tuskegee, ranked 23rd in NCAA Division II, routed Stillman 49-20 at Abbott Stadium. 
“The defense played great today,” Morgan said. “I love my brothers. We all sold out for the team, and I can’t ask for anything more than that. If we keep playing like this, we’ll keep winning.” 
The Golden Tigers (6-1, 2-0 SIAC West) held Stillman to 165 total yards and forced four turnovers. 
Tuskegee linebacker Osband Thompson’s 65-yard interception return for a touchdown with 11:56 left in the first quarter gave Tuskegee a 6-0 lead and set the tone for the Tuskegee defense. Linebacker Jewell Ratliff had 10 stops. 
“We don’t feel like we’re on top of world as a defense,” said Thompson, who had another interception and eight tackles. “There are some things that we need to improve on. Today, we competed hard, and we have to play smarter.” 
Tuskegee did commit 21 penalties for 221 yards, something head coach Willie Slater said will hurt this team moving forward. 
“There were just too many of them,” Slater said. “Our defense was awesome today and gave us some short fields. We expect to score with that kind of field position. I’ll have to watch the tape to see the personal fouls and try to do something to get that fixed.” 
The offense finally got going in the second quarter for Tuskegee as it gained 175 of its 428 total yards. 
Tuskegee quarterback Kevin Lacey completed 8 of 13 passes for 170 yards and a touchdown while being sacked three times. Tyree Brooks rushed for 53 yards and two touchdowns on seven carries. 
Running back Dennis Norfleet, who rushed for 74 yards on four carries, left the game with a shoulder injury. Devozea Gaines returned a kickoff 83 yards for a touchdown early in the fourth quarter for Tuskegee 
Stillman (3-3, 1-1) finished just two of 14 on third downs and picked up only 10 first downs. The Tigers went 3-for-3 in the red zone. 
Stillman quarterback Brett Standifer completed 4 of 8 passes for 34 yards with two interceptions and was sacked twice. Backup quarterback Mikiel Clemmons had two touchdown runs, and running back Rovonta Johnson rushed for 18 yards on nine carries. 
Stillman fumbled twice deep in its own territory late in the second quarter, setting up a 10-yard touchdown pass to Leo Gilbert and a 7-yard run by Tyree Brooks to make the score 29-0 at halftime. 
Ruben Sartain led the Stillman defense with six tackles. Michael Herrod had five tackles and a fumble recovery. Everett Curry also had five stops. 
Tuskegee now holds a 10-1 all-time record against Stillman with its only loss coming in 2011. Slater has a 9-1 record against Stillman. 
Tuskegee, now 5-0 against SIAC teams this season, will visit Kentucky State at noon next Saturday. Its final four games are against division foes. 
“We knew that the bull’s-eye would be on our back this year,” Morgan said. “That just means we need to grind even harder and fight from the first down to the last down.” Buy Photo Tuskegee running back Dennis Norfleet goes airborne for a moment while running deep near the end zone.
